update.description:
Hopefully the documentation in the header is enough description of the new functionality.

An earlier version of this plugin used an Ignition Transport service, but to work with Gazebo 7, this version uses a Gazebo Transport topic for the "enable service". This is the same approach taken for the `TouchPlugin`.

It's worth mentioning that this plugin offers functionality similar to `SimEventsPlugin` with an `OccupiedEventSource`, but that only supports world-aligned boxes. At the time when I implemented the new plugin for SRCSim, I looked into extending SimEvents to also support oriented boxes, but I think that would break ABI since that plugin is not using the PIMPL pattern, so I went with a custom approach. I believe the new plugin has a few new features, such as the enabling functionality and a custom topic, so I think it's worth it adding it to Gazebo alongside SimEvents. Please speak up if you think otherwise.

## Try it out

1. Open demo world: `gazebo worlds/box_contains_plugin_demo.world`

1. On a new terminal echo the contains topic: `gz topic -e /gazebo/default/drill/box/contains`

1. Drag the drill into the box

![boxcontains.gif](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2802660915-boxcontains.gif)
update.title: Port Box Contains plugin from SRCSim

content.raw:
suggestion for future: could make this consistent with <geometry> tag for people who are familiar with existing sdf spec

~~~
<pose>10 10 0.5 0 0 0.8</pose>
<geometry>
  <box>
    <size>1 1 2<size>
  </box>
</geometry>
~~~
content.html:
suggestion for future: could make this consistent with <geometry> tag for people who are familiar with existing sdf spec

<pose>10 10 0.5 0 0 0.8</pose>
<geometry>
  <box>
    <size>1 1 2<size>
  </box>
</geometry>

pullrequest.title: Port Box Contains plugin from SRCSim

content.raw: I think it's worth it calling `GetEntity` at every iteration until we find it. If the user is planing to take a while until the model is inserted, they have the option to start the plugin disabled.
content.html: I think it's worth it calling GetEntity at every iteration until we find it. If the user is planing to take a while until the model is inserted, they have the option to start the plugin disabled.

pull_request.title: Port Box Contains plugin from SRCSim

pullrequest.title: Port Box Contains plugin from SRCSim

content.raw: I think the typical use case through ROS is to dynamically spawn the model into the world. In this case, the user will need to make an addition call to enable the plugin. The alternative approach is to call GetModel on every iteration if plugin is enabled until the model is found but that's less efficient.
content.html: I think the typical use case through ROS is to dynamically spawn the model into the world. In this case, the user will need to make an addition call to enable the plugin. The alternative approach is to call GetModel on every iteration if plugin is enabled until the model is found but that's less efficient.

pull_request.title: Port Box Contains plugin from SRCSim

pullrequest.title: Port Box Contains plugin from SRCSim

content.raw: Yes, right now it only covers exact entities (not only models, but also links, etc). The use case for a "family" of models is interesting, but I think it could become time-consuming to loop through all entities in the world and comparing names. It would be nice if the world offered a function to get entities based on a regex...
content.html: Yes, right now it only covers exact entities (not only models, but also links, etc). The use case for a "family" of models is interesting, but I think it could become time-consuming to loop through all entities in the world and comparing names. It would be nice if the world offered a function to get entities based on a regex...

content.html: Correct, I moved this logic to Enable, rather than the constructor in case users want to turn this on after a certain model was inserted into the world. Let me know if you can think of an alternative which is useful.

content.raw: Are you going to target a different version of this plugin that uses ignition transport to `gazebo8` or default? I understand if not.
content.html: Are you going to target a different version of this plugin that uses ignition transport to gazebo8 or default? I understand if not.

pull_request.title: Port Box Contains plugin from SRCSim

update.description:
Hopefully the documentation in the header is enough description of the new functionality.

An earlier version of this plugin used an Ignition Transport service, but to work with Gazebo 7, this version uses a Gazebo Transport topic for the "enable service". This is the same approach taken for the `TouchPlugin`.

It's worth mentioning that this plugin offers functionality similar to `SimEventsPlugin` with an `OccupiedEventSource`, but that only supports world-aligned boxes. At the time when I implemented the new plugin for SRCSim, I looked into extending SimEvents to also support oriented boxes, but I think that would break ABI since that plugin is not using the PIMPL pattern, so I went with a custom approach. I believe the new plugin has a few new features, such as the enabling functionality and a custom topic, so I think it's worth it adding it to Gazebo alongside SimEvents. Please speak up if you think otherwise.

## Try it out

1. Open demo world: `gazebo worlds/box_contains_plugin_demo.world`

1. On a new terminal echo the contains topic: `gz topic -e /gazebo/default/drill/box/contains`

1. Drag the drill into the box

![boxcontains.gif](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2802660915-boxcontains.gif)
update.title: Port Box Contains plugin from SRCSim
